    GlobalMass

    globalmass.Rmd

    NOTE: This vignette is a work in progress and some of the functionality shown below does not yet exist.

    You can run through this tutorial using an interactive R session or an R Notebook. We’ll first start by making sure we have the data files required.

    We provide an example dataset for this tutorial which is available on our GitHub page under 4d_modeller_test_data. To get started we’ll create a globalmass_tutorial directory in our home folder, but you can put it wherever you like.

    mkdir globalmass_tutorial
cd globalmass_tutorial

    The next step is to download the tutorial data from our repository. We provide a helper function to do this so first we’ll load the processing library and run retrieve_tutorial_data. Note that throughout this tutorial we’ll prepend all of the calls to processing functions with ::. This makes it clear where the functions originate.

    library(processing)
processing::retrieve_tutorial_data()

    We can have a quick look at the data we’ve retrieved

    ls tutorial_data

    Here the raw_data folder contains the data needed for the BHM and the shapefiles directory contains the data required to create the meshes the model will use. Now we’re ready to process this data into a useful format.

    Creating meshes

    Setup

    To avoid the need to run the meshing and data pre-processing steps each time we run the model, we’ll first create an intermediate_data folder in our globalmass_tutorial folder.

    mkdir intermediate_data

    We’ll use this folder to store all the intermediate data such as meshes and processed data that is ready to feed into the BHM.

    Creating a mesh

    The first mesh we create will be one for glaciers and ice caps (GIC). We’ll use the file 0.5degree_grid_shapefile_Ant_GrIS_removed.shp

    library(processing)

gic_shapefile_path = processing::get_tutorial_datapath("0.5degree_grid_shapefile_Ant_GrIS_removed.shp")

gic_mesh_path = processing::create_gic_mesh(input_filepath = gic_shapefile_path,  output_folder="intermediate_data")

gic_mesh_path

    Now we’ve created our GIC mesh we’re ready to move on to creating the data required by the BHM.

    Pre-process data

    The data we need to run the BHM over glaciers and ice caps is stored in the file 0.5deg_cumulative_mass_change_tseries.txt.tar.bz2. This is a compressed file containing a large amount of information, but we don’t have to worry about decompressing it, processing will handle that for us.

    We pass the filename to get_tutorial_datapath and the function will handle the decompression and return a useful filepath to us.

    gic_raw_data = processing::get_tutorial_datapath("0.5deg_cumulative_mass_change_tseries.txt.tar.bz2")

gic_raw_data

    We’ll use process_hugonnet_tiles to process the data into a format the BHM expects.

    processed_data_filepath = processing::process_hugonnet_tiles(input_filepath = gic_raw_data, output_folder = "intermediate_data")

processed_data_filepath

    We now have both components we need to feed into the BHM, the mesh file and the intermediate data file.

    Running the BHM

    To run the BHM we’ll use the 4D Modeller stats package.
